abstract: Surveys of manufacturers in many countries appear to indicate that the trade-led recovery of 2010 and 2011 is stalling out or even reversing. lead_paragraph: Jay Goltz, like any normal person, hates firing people. The commenters on his post about firing brought up a wide range of subjects, but one issue that wasn’t addressed is the actual mechanics of firing. I don’t have wide experience with this, but over the last 26 years, I have had to fire five workers for breaking the rules, and I also laid off 11 people one day in 2008. If you are a boss, the day will arrive when you have to fire someone.

lead_paragraph: Adam & Eve, London, an independent agency opened in 2008, was acquired by DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, which will merge the agency with DDB United Kingdom, London, to create Adam & Eve/DDB. Financial terms were not disclosed; the Web site of the British trade publication Campaign estimated the cost of the deal at $92.5 million. James Murphy, a founder of Adam & Eve, becomes chief executive at Adam & Eve/DDB, and Stephen Woodford, chief executive at DDB United Kingdom, becomes chairman at Adam & Eve/DDB. The deal echoed one in 1989 when DDB bought Boase Massimi Pollitt, an independent London agency opened in 1968, and merged it with the DDB London office to form BMP DDB; that name lasted until 2004.

abstract: Also, a big deal involving Taylor Swift will finally give labels and performers a cut of radio revenue.
snippet: Also, a big deal involving Taylor Swift will finally give labels and performers a cut of radio revenue.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift and her record label may be reversing decades of music economics with a new deal struck with Clear Channel, the nation’s largest radio operator, writes Ben Sisario. The deal would give the label and performer royalties for traditional radio play — something the music business has long fought for and never received. In return, the label agreed to accept a cut for online radio play (which does award royalties to performers and labels), giving Clear Channel at least some measure of predictability in online payments. Online play is a tiny part of Clear Channel’s business but the company saw an opportunity to preemptively control costs.

headline.main: The Breakfast Meeting: Warren Buffett Likes Newspapers, and Barbara Walters Apologizes

abstract: An analysis of the mismanagement of MF Global provides a damaging look at how the firm was pushed to collapse, but whether prosecutors have enough to pursue criminal charges is a different question.
snippet: An analysis of the mismanagement of MF Global provides a damaging look at how the firm was pushed to collapse, but whether prosecutors have enough to pursue criminal charges is a different question.
lead_paragraph: Much as the mythical Icarus plunged to his death after he flew too close to the sun, the trustee’s report on the demise of MF Global shows how the firm pushed the permissible uses of customer money to the edge until the firm collapsed. The question is whether prosecutors can build a criminal case or whether management stayed close enough to the line to avoid being charged.

headline.main: Assessing a Case Against MF Global Executives

lead_paragraph: Ray Bradbury, who conjured up life on Mars, virtual reality and, perhaps most shockingly, a world without books, died on Tuesday at age 91. His was a prolific professional writing career – that produced novels, short stories, a screenplay and plays — that spanned 70 years, Gerald Jonas writes. The impulse began in childhood, he wrote in an autobiographical essay for The New Yorker. “It was one frenzy after one elation after one enthusiasm after one hysteria after another,” he wrote, noting, “You rarely have such fevers later in life that fill your entire day with emotion.”

lead_paragraph: For years, the government of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria has used high-priced public relations advisers — veterans of the Clinton, Bush and Thatcher administrations — to portray themselves in the Western media as accessible, progressive and even glamorous, Bill Carter and Amy Chozick write. Until recently, the Assad government had a couple of obvious things working in its favor, in the words of a Middle East expert who once worked for a charity sponsored by Mr. Assad’s wife, Asma: “He speaks English, and his wife is hot.” The violent crackdown against the political opposition there has changed that friendly calculus — something the longtime ABC News correspondent Barbara Walters found out this week.

abstract: After thinking long and hard, SaneBox, which helps users manage their e-mail in-boxes, decided to charge for its services.
snippet: After thinking long and hard, SaneBox, which helps users manage their e-mail in-boxes, decided to charge for its services.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Dashboard roundup of small-business news includes a link to an article by Dmitri Leonov that challenges the “freemium” business model. Increasingly popular on the Web, the model involves offering basic products or services free but charging a premium for advanced features or functionality (Chris Anderson famously proclaimed “free” the future of business in 2008). I decided to follow up with a few questions for Mr. Leonov, who is vice president for growth at SaneBox, a company that helps users spend less time in their in-box by filtering out and summarizing unimportant e-mails (for a fee!). The following is a condensed version of our e-mail conversation.

headline.main: Drilling Down: Does the ‘Freemium’ Model Really Work?

abstract: By taking the time to write a manual, I am demonstrating to my workers that I intend to take a rational approach to the boss/employee relationship.
snippet: By taking the time to write a manual, I am demonstrating to my workers that I intend to take a rational approach to the boss/employee relationship.
lead_paragraph: There were lots of comments to my post on how I fire people, and I’d like to address some of the points. Commenters raised two main issues: First, that the policies I outlined in my employee manual are written for the benefit of the company as opposed to the employee and, second, that I seemed to be favoring firing people instead of training them. Both of these are complex issues that are handled differently by different companies. I can only comment on my own thoughts and experiences. Please don’t blame me for the many, many bad bosses and companies out there.

headline.main: The Balance of Power Between Bosses and Workers

Last week, the Republican-led House Appropriations Committee unveiled its bill (pdf) to finance the S.B.A. and several other government agencies, and what is most notable about the four pages dealing with the S.B.A. is the prospect for comity, not conflict.

Russian-made helicopters are en route to Syria, sold to the Assad regime by Rosoboronexport, the Russian state-owned arms exporter. Since 2007, Rosoboronexport, the sole Russian arms exporter, has supplied Syria with 78 percent of its arms imports, according to the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute. (The New York Times has reported that the copters heading to Syria were most likely already part of that country’s fleet, returning after routine maintenance in Russia.)

abstract: Is a candy company that gives tours to children taking a risk if it does not hire criminals?
snippet: Is a candy company that gives tours to children taking a risk if it does not hire criminals?
lead_paragraph: Second chances come up often when you talk to business owners on the record about hiring people who have served time — the subject, indirectly, of a just-published Times story about the new rules from the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission that may limit using criminal records in hiring decisions. Joseph Dutra, who employs 23 people at Kimmie Candy Company in Reno, Nev., is willing to give somebody with a criminal history a second chance, provided the crime didn’t include violence or a sexual advance on a child. “We don’t have a blanket policy here, but we need to have people with good morals, who are compatible with the public that we bring in,” said Mr. Dutra, who added that groups of schoolchildren often tour the factory. “We’re trying to make this a fun little place where people can come and feel safe.”

abstract: Three gadgets represent small steps by technology into the kitchen: a rice cooker, a kitchen thermometer and an espresso coffee maker.

lead_paragraph: We expect technology in certain places. We even welcome it. Technology in the workplace? A given. At home in the living room? Awesome — more movies to watch, more music to listen to, more games to play. When we’re traveling? Also a boon. We gain a wealth of information, and therefore power, as we compare fares, rebook canceled flights and find taxis in strange cities at odd hours.

headline.main: Digital Wizardry Meant to Impress the Cook
headline.print_headline: Digital Wizardry Meant To Impress The Cook

abstract: A conventional piston-driven internal-combustion engine functions by performing a cycle with four main steps: Air intake, air compression, combustion and exhaust. An engine is referred to as a “four-" or “two-stroke” model according to the number of movements the piston makes to perform one cycle. The Scuderi split-cycle engine and EcoMotor OPOC engine are both departures from the four-stroke engine most commonly found in automobiles. By revisiting and perfecting existing technologies, the companies say their motors provide more power, lower emissions and significantly better fuel efficiency.

abstract: “Augmented reality” is the term for the instant availability of information and options that populate your immediate surroundings. Two apps, Layar and Junaio, are good introductions.
snippet: “Augmented reality” is the term for the instant availability of information and options that populate your immediate surroundings. Two apps, Layar and Junaio, are good introductions.
lead_paragraph: A relaxed late evening stroll along the esplanade in my seaside hometown may not seem like the ideal opportunity to test out what may be the cutting edge of mobile app technology, but it was this week. On the walk I’d noticed an enormously large cargo ship, with giant cranes on its deck, floating in the sunset haze a few miles out at sea, and I was curious what the ship was named and where she was from. Fortunately there was an app for that. An augmented reality app.

headline.main: Apps That Present Highlights of the World in Front of You

lead_paragraph: Built in 1920, the brick warehouse at 4444 Second Avenue in Detroit used to be a showroom for the city’s pride: Model T-based automobiles. Now it’s a metaphor for urban reinvention. lead_paragraph: Local governments, transit systems and school districts have been offering up advertising and sponsorship deals that encroach on basic services and equipment, including ads on school buses, sponsorship of subway stations, or (temporary) ads on fire hydrants and manhole covers, Michael Cooper writes. The deals — like one being considered in Baltimore to allow advertisements on fire trucks — seemingly serve a need for each side. Cash-strapped cities averse to raising taxes can help pay the bills with the revenue from sponsorship deals. (By renaming its Bus Rapid Transit system the HealthLine, Cleveland received $6.25 million over 25 years.) And, Mr. Cooper writes, advertisers can “try to reach consumers who have grown more adept at tuning out commercials, whether with remote controls or digital video recorders.”

lead_paragraph: With this post, The Agenda returns to our occasional series on how small companies are coping with providing health insurance. We’re going to Woodinville, Wash., about a half hour north of Seattle, and The Herbfarm Restaurant. The Herbfarm, which grows many of its own ingredients in its garden and nearby fields, has also cultivated a distinguished national reputation since it opened more than two decades ago. The travel guide Frommer’s once declared that the restaurant is “so famous and serves such unforgettable meals that people plan Seattle vacations around dinner here,” but that hasn’t made it any easier for its proprietors to provide affordable insurance to their employees.
